## Configure Microsoft 365 
***
***
***
Follow the steps given below to integrate Microsoft as a Single Sign-On (SSO) Service Provider with ${productName} using the SAML 2.0 protocol.
***
***
***
***    
> - You need an Office 365 Business account with admin access and a domain added as per the [Microsoft documentation]( https://learn.microsoft.com/en-gb/microsoft-365/admin/setup/add-domain?view=o365-worldwide&redirectSourcePath=%252fen-us%252farticle%252fadd-a-domain-to-office-365-6383f56d-3d09-4dcb-9b41-b5f5a5efd611).
> - Ensure that PowerShell is installed.
<!--rehype:type=info&title=Prerequisites-->
***
***
***
***
### Install the required modules and connect to Microsoft Azure AD
<!--rehype:numbered=true&content=1-->
***
***
***
Start PowerShell and install the Microsoft Graph Powershell SDK.
***
***
```bash
Install-Module Microsoft.Graph -Scope CurrentUser -Repository PSGallery -Force
```
***
***
Verify that the Graph SDK is installed.
***
***
```bash
Get-InstalledModule Microsoft.Graph
```
***
***
***
### Configure Azure AD Domain Federation
<!--rehype:numbered=true&content=2-->
***
***
***
Connect to Your Microsoft Entra Directory.
***
***
```powershell
Connect-MgGraph -Scopes "Domain.ReadWrite.All"
```
***
***
***
Configure the domain as a federated domain by providing the respective federation settings that match the ${productName}. Store the federation settings in parameters.
***
***
```bash
$Domain = "yourdomain.com"
$DisplayName = "Login with ${productName}"
$LogOnUrl = "${metadata.saml.ssoUrl}"
$LogOffUrl = "${metadata.saml.sloUrl}"
$IssuerName = "${metadata.saml.issuer}"
$IDPResponseSigningCert = "${metadata.saml.certificate}"
$Protocol = "saml"
$MfaBehavior = "rejectMfaByFederatedIdp"

New-MgDomainFederationConfiguration `
  -DomainId $Domain `
  -DisplayName $DisplayName `
  -IssuerUri $IssuerName `
  -PassiveSignInUri $LogOnUrl `
  -PreferredAuthenticationProtocol $Protocol `
  -SignOutUri $LogOffUrl `
  -SigningCertificate $IDPResponseSigningCert `
  -FederatedIdpMfaBehavior $MfaBehavior
```
***
***
Verify the configured federation settings for your domain.
***
***
```powershell
Get-MgDomainFederationConfiguration -DomainId "yourdomain.com"
```
***
***
If you wish to redo the configurations, run the following command to first remove the federation configurations of your domain. Use the ID of the previously created domain federation configuration for `InternalDomainFederationId`.
***
***
```powershell
Remove-MgDomainFederationConfiguration `
  -DomainId "yourdomain.com" `
  -InternalDomainFederationId "2a8ce608-bb34-473f-9e0f-f373cbc5a"
```
***
***
***
***
### Try Out SSO
<!--rehype:numbered=true&content=3-->
***
***
***
To test the SSO, [create a user](/users) on the ${productName}. Then, add that same user to Microsoft using the following command. Here, the `OnPremisesImmutableId` should be the UUID of the user. 
***
***
```powershell
$Password = "p@ssword1"
$PasswordProfile = @{ Password = "$Password" }

New-MgUser `
  -UserPrincipalName "john@yourdomain.com" `
  -DisplayName "John Doe" `
  -GivenName "John" `
  -Surname "Doe" `
  -AccountEnabled `
  -MailNickName "JohnDoe" `
  -OnPremisesImmutableId "ABCDEFG1234567890" `
  -PasswordProfile $PasswordProfile `
  -UsageLocation "US"
```
***
***

> Alternatively, you can automate the user synchronization using Powershell Cmdlets as well. For more information, refer to the [Microsoft Entra ID documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/hybrid/connect/how-to-connect-fed-saml-idp#provision-user-principals-to-microsoft-entra-id--microsoft-365).

***
***

You can access Microsoft 365 portal via [https://portal.office.com](https://portal.office.com). When you enter the user's email address (eg: `john@yourdomain.com`), you'll be automatically redirected to the ${productName} login page to complete the authentication.
